https://s3.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-us-east/content/pii:S1381116915002149/mmc1/MAIN/application/msword/1ed74f8b88ef5754ecb1254cbcf98bbf/mmc1.doc mmc1 mmc1.doc doc 594432 APPLICATION MOLCAA 9516 S1381-1169(15)00214-9 10.1016/j.molcata.2015.06.002 Elsevier B.V. Scheme 1 Structure of ligand H2hap-iah (I). Scheme 2 Synthetic routes to prepare 1 and 2. PS represents the backbone of the chloromethylated polystyrene. Scheme 3 NaHCO3 activated oxidation products of styrene using H2O2 as the oxidant. Scheme 4 NaHCO3 activated oxidation product of cyclohexene using H2O2 as the oxidant. Scheme 5 Proposed catalytic mechanism for the oxidation of alkenes. Fig. 1 Scanning electron micrographs (SEM) of chloromethylated polystyrene (a) and PS-[MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (2) (b). Fig. 2 AFM images (left) and respective 3d-views (right) of PS-CH2Cl (A) and PS-[MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (B). Fig. 3 (A) Electronic spectra of (a) H2hap-iah (I) and (b) [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (1) recorded in methanol. (B) Electronic spectrum of PS-[MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (2) recorded after dispersing it in nujol®. Fig. 4 1H NMR spectra of H2hap-iah (I) and [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (1). Fig. 5 (a) Effect of amount of catalyst on the oxidation of styrene. (b) Effect of amount of NaHCO3 on the oxidation of styrene. (c) Effect of amount of H2O2 (H2O2/styrene molar ratio) on the oxidation of styrene. (d) Effect of volume of CH3CN on the oxidation of styrene. (e) Effect of temperature on the oxidation of styrene. For reaction conditions refer to Table 3. Fig. 6 UV–vis spectral changes observed during titration of [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (1) with H2O2. The spectra recorded after successive addition of one drop portions of dilute H2O2 (1 drop of 30% H2O2 in 10mLMeOH) to 25mL of 5.32×10−5 M methanolic solution of 1. Inset shows similar spectral changes with 3.33×10−4 M solution of 1 in methanol. Table 1 IR spectral data (cm−1) of compounds. (%) TOF (h−1) 1 0.010 0.168, 2 1.135, 10 5 60 67 605 2 0.020 0.168, 2 1.135, 10 5 60 78 352 3 0.030 0.168, 2 1.135, 10 5 60 95 286 4 0.040 0.168, 2 1.135, 10 5 60 98 664 5 0.030 0.168, 2 0.567, 5 5 60 27 081 6 0.030 0.168, 2 0.851, 7.5 5 60 82 247 7 0.030 0.168, 2 1.70, 15 5 60 99 298 8 0.030 0.084, 1 1.135, 10 5 60 69 208 9 0.030 0.126, 1.5 1.135, 10 5 60 95 286 10 0.030 0.252, 3 1.135, 10 5 60 97 292 11 0.030 0.126, 1.5 1.135, 10 3 60 95 286 12 0.030 0.126, 1.5 1.135, 10 7 60 74 223 13 0.030 0.126, 1.5 1.135, 10 10 60 26 078 14 0.030 0.126, 1.5 1.135, 10 3 30 32 096 15 0.030 0.126, 1.5 1.135, 10 3 40 75 226 16 0.030 0.126, 1.5 1.135, 10 3 50 93 280 Sodium bicarbonate assisted oxidation, by H2O2, of styrene and cyclohexene using polymer grafted dioxidomolybdenum(VI) complex as a catalyst Mannar R. Maurya ⁎ Naveen Kumar Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee, Roorkee 247667, India Department of Chemistry Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee Roorkee 247667 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +91 1332 285327; fax: +91 1332 273560. Graphical abstract Polymer-grafted dioxidomolybdenum(VI) complex and its catalytic potential for the oxidation of styrene and cyclohexene are reported. Ligand H2hap-iah (I), obtained by the condensation of equimolar amounts of o-hydroxy acetophenone (hap) and indole-3-acetic hydrazide (iah) reacts with [MoVIO2(acac)2] in 1:1 ratio in refluxing methanol to give [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (1). Complex 1 has been grafted in chloromethylated polystyrene cross-linked with 5% divinylbenzene {now abbreviated as PS-[MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (2)} via covalent bonding through imino nitrogen of the indole group. Both complexes are characterized by various spectroscopic techniques (IR, electronic, 1H, and 13C NMR), analytical and thermal studies. Complex 2 has also been analyzed by atomic force microscopy (AFM), field-emission scanning electron micrographs (FE-SEM) as well as energy dispersive X-ray (EDAX) studies. The polymer-grafted compound 2 was used for the catalytic oxidation of styrene and cyclohexene in the presence of NaHCO3 using aqueous H2O2 as oxidant. The intermediate peroxido species, expected to be involved during catalytic action, was also generated from the solution of 1 and studied by UV–vis. Various reaction conditions were considered to optimize reactions conditions for the maximum oxidation of substrates. Styrene under optimized reaction conditions gave mainly styrene oxide as a major product. Oxidation of cyclohexene gave cyclohexene oxide selectively. The polymer-grafted complex shows higher conversions than its neat counterpart. The polymer-grafted complex provides additional advantage over its homogeneous counterpart in terms of increased catalyst lifetime and easier separation from the reaction mixture and allows for recyclable catalytic system. Keywords Dioxidomolybdenum(VI) complexes NMR studies Polymer-grafted molybdenum complex Oxidation of styrene Oxidation of cyclohexene 1 Introduction Development of polymer-grafted metal complexes based catalysts, having potentials for technological applications for environmentally benign synthetic routes to fine chemicals, have attracted attention of researchers [1–10]. Our effort using chloromethylated polystyrene cross-linked with divinylbenzene (PS-CH2Cl) as a solid support to graft vanadium complexes and use them as catalyst precursors have contributed much in this direction because of their thermal stability, recyclability, and high turnover rates [9,10]. Homogeneous molybdenum complexes have potential catalytic applications in the oxidation and oxidative bromination of organic substrates including oxidation of sulfides [11–29]. However, immobilizations of these homogeneous catalysts on solid support and exploit them as potential industrial catalysts find limited entry in the literature [6–8,29]. In our recent effort we reported polymer grafted dioxidomolybdenum(VI) complex and demonstrated its catalytic potential for the oxidative bromination of organic substrates. Spacer (extra CH2 with indole group) presents between polymer support and catalyst improved the performance of the catalyst by allowing the effective interaction of catalytic center with substrates and oxidant during catalytic reaction [30]. The objective of the present work is the grafting of dioxidomolybdenum(VI) complex of the indole-derived ONO donor ligand H2hap-iah (I, Scheme 1 ) into chloromethylated polystyrene, its characterization and study catalytic potential towards the oxidation of styrene and cyclohexene in the presence of NaHCO3. It has been found that NaHCO3 improves catalytic efficiency for the oxidation of organic compounds in presence of H2O2 as terminal oxidant [31–34]. The corresponding non polymer-grafted molybdenum complex has also been prepared which helped in proposing suitable reaction mechanism and comparing its catalytic performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Analytical reagent grade ammonium molybdate (S.D. Fine, India), o-hydroxy acetophenone (Loba Chemie, India), acetyl acetone, cyclohexene (Sisco Research, India), indole-3-acetic hydrazide, styrene (Aldrich, USA) and 30% aqueous H2O2, (Rankem, India) were used as obtained. Chloromethylated polystyrene (18.9% Cl) cross-linked with 5% divinylbenzene was obtained from Thermax Limited, Pune, India. [MoVIO2(acac)2] [35] and H2hap-iah [36] were prepared according to the reported methods. Other chemicals and solvents of analytical reagent grades were used without purifications. 2.2 Physical methods and analysis C, H, and, N analyses of the neat complex were obtained from an Elementar model Vario-EL-III. Molybdenum content in polymer-grafted complex was obtained by inductively coupled plasma spectrometry (ICP; Labtam 8440 Plasma Lab). Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out using Perkin-Elmer (Pyris Diamond) having weight sensitivity of 0.2μg under oxygen atmosphere. IR spectra were recorded (16 scans) as KBr pellets on a Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer having a resolution of 4cm−1. Electronic spectra of the polymer-grafted complex was recorded with a medium scan speed in Nujol on a Shimadzu 1601 UV–vis spectrophotometer having 0.1nm wavelength accuracy by layering a mull of the sample on the inside of one of the cuvettes while keeping the other one layered with Nujol as reference. Spectra of ligand and neat complexes were recorded in methanol. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were obtained using Bruker Avance III 500MHz spectrometer. The energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDAX) of anchored complex was obtained on a FEI Quanta 200 FEG. The samples were coated with a thin film of gold to prevent surface charging, to protect the surface material from thermal damage by the electron beam and to make the sample conductive. The two and three -dimensional images of the samples were recorded by atomic force microscopy (AFM, NTEGRE (NTMDT)) in semi-contact mode. A Shimadzu 2010 plus gas-chromatograph fitted with an Rtx-1 capillary column (30m×0.25mm×0.25μm) and a FID detector was used to analyze the reaction products and their quantifications were made on the basis of the relative peak area of the respective product. The identity of the products was confirmed using a GC–MS Perkin-Elmer, model Clarus 500 and comparing the fragments of each product with the library available. 2.3 Synthesis 2.3.1 [MoVIO2(hap-iah) (MeOH)] (1) A stirred solution of H2hap-iah (0.307g, 1mmol) in methanol (15mL) was treated with [MoVIO2(acac)2] (0.329g, 1mmol) dissolved in methanol (15mL) and the obtained reaction mixture was refluxed for ca. 6h on a water bath. After reducing the solvent volume to ca. 10mL and standing the solution at room temperature in air for 24h, the yellow crystalline compound precipitated which was filtered off, washed with methanol and dried in vacuo. Yield 0.39g (84%) Anal. Cal. for C19H19N3O5Mo (465): C, 49.09; H, 4.12; N, 9.03. Found: C, 48.8; H, 4.1; N, 9.1%. 2.3.2 PS-[MoVIO2(hap-iah) (MeOH)] (2) Chloromethylated polystyrene (2.0g) was suspended in DMF (15mL) to swell for 2h. A solution of [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (2.0g, 4.28mmol) in DMF (15mL) was added to the above suspension followed by triethylamine (2.66g) in ethylacetate (15mL), and the obtained reaction mixture was heated at 90°C for 36h with continuous but slow stirring. After cooling to room temperature, the polymer-grafted complex was separated by filtration, washed with hot DMF, followed by hot methanol and dried in an oven in air at 110°C. 2.4 Catalytic activity Polymer-grafted catalyst was initially kept in CH3CN for 1h before use. The catalytic oxidation of styrene and cyclohexene was carried out in a 50mL flask fitted with a water circulated condenser. 2.4.1 Oxidation of styrene In a typical reaction, styrene (0.52g, 5mmol), catalyst (0.030g), aqueous 30% H2O2 (1.70g, 15mmol) and NaHCO3 (0.168g, 2mmol) were placed in acetonitrile (5mL) with stirring and the temperature of the reaction mixture was set to 60°C for 4h. At every 1h small aliquot of the reaction mixture was withdrawn, extracted by n-hexane and analyzed quantitatively by gas chromatograph. Only one product was formed whose identity was confirmed by GC–MS. The effects of various parameters, such as amount of oxidant, amount of sodium bicarbonate, catalyst, temperature, and solvent volume were studied to see their effect on the conversion and selectivity of the reaction product. 2.4.2 Oxidation of cyclohexene Catalyst (0.030g), cyclohexene (0.410g, 5mmol), NaHCO3 (0.126g, 1.5mmol), aqueous 30% H2O2 (1.135g, 10mmol) were stirred at 50°C in 3mL of CH3CN for 3h. At every 30min small aliquot of the reaction mixture was withdrawn, extracted by n-hexane and analyzed quantitatively by gas chromatograph. Only one product was formed which was confirmed by GC–MS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization Equimolar amounts of indole-3-acetic hydrazide and o-hydroxyacetophenone react in refluxing methanol to give ligand H2hap-iah (I). Its reaction with [MoVIO2(acac)2] in 1:1 ratio in refluxing MeOH gave [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (1). The whole synthetic procedure is presented in Scheme 2 . The complex is fairly soluble in methanol, DMF, and DMSO. Its structure was confirmed by elemental analyses, spectroscopic characterization (IR, electronic, 1H, and 13C NMR) and thermogravimetric pattern. The ligand coordinates through its dianionic (ONO) functionalities. The reaction of chloromethylated polystyrene (cross linked with 5% divinylbenzene) with dioxidomolybdenum(VI) complex 1 in DMF at 90°C in the presence of triethylamine leads to the formation of polymer-grafted complex PS-[MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (2). The labile proton of NH group of the indole reacts with CH2Cl group of polymer during this process (Scheme 2). The ICP-MS analysis of molybdenum in the polymer-grafted complex suggests molybdenum loading of 0.31mmolg−1 of polymer in 2. 3.2 Field emission-scanning electron micrograph (FE-SEM) and energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDAX) studies A comparative study using FE-SEM along with EDAX was carried out taking single bead of pure chloromethylated polystyrene and polymer-grafted complex 2. The pure chloromethylated polystyrene bead has smooth and flat surface and shows mainly carbon and chlorine contents on the surface, as evaluated by energy dispersive X-ray analysis, while beads of grafted complex show slight darkening of the top layer suggesting the inclusion of metal complex into polymer matrices. Due to insertion of spacer between polymer support and complex, the presence of some of the metal centers on the surface of the polymer was spotted by EDAX study where as high as 7% molybdenum content was noted along with C, N, O, and Cl, confirming the grafting of metal complex in polystyrene beads. These observations suggest that part of the covalently bonded complex is present on the surface while remaining is at various sites. The EDAX profile (see Fig. S1 of SI) and the images of field emission-scanning electron micrographs (FE-SEM) of single beads of pure chloromethylated polystyrene and polymer-grafted complex PS-[MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (2) are presented in Fig. 1 . 3.3 Atomic force microscopic (AFM) study We have obtained AFM images (Fig. 2 , left) and respective 3d views (Fig 2, right) of PS-CH2Cl and PS-[MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (2) to see morphological changes before and after complex grafting. The surface roughness and mean height as measured by AFM are 76.5nm and 484.7nm, respectively, for PS-CH2Cl whereas, these values are 52.2nm, 310.0nm, respectively, for PS-[MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (2). The net reduction in these values confirms the grafting of complex in the pores of PS-CH2Cl beads [37,38–40]. This observation supplements the conclusion drawn from ICP-MS, TGA, and EDAX. 3.4 Thermogravimetric study Thermogravimetric analysis profile of [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (1) under an oxygen atmosphere shows its stability up to ca. 120°C. There after it loses weight exothermically between 120 and 180°C equivalent to one coordinated methanol (Obs. 6.6%; Anal. Cal. 6.8%). The solvent free complex decomposes in two major fragments with exothermic weight loss on further increasing the temperature. This decomposition completes at ca. 540°C with the formation of 29.9% MoO3 (theoretical value=30.9%). The weight loss of polymer-grafted complex PS-[MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (2) starts at ca. 100°C and completes at ca. 300°C with a total loss of ca. 15% suggesting the presence of coordinated as well as trapped solvent. On further increasing the temperature it decomposes with exothermic weight loss in three overlapping fragments. The final residue of 5.0% (equivalent to 0.34mmolg−1 of Mo in 2) at ca. 470°C suggests the formation of MoO3 and grafting of complex 1 into polymer. 3.5 IR spectral studies The IR spectral data of Schiff base ligand (I) and molybdenum complexes (1 and 2) are given in Table 1 . The IR spectrum of ligand exhibits two distinct bands at 3190 and 1672cm−1 due to ν(NH)amide and ν(CO) modes, respectively, indicative of its ketonic nature in the solid state. The absence of these bands in the spectra of both complexes suggests the enolisation of the amide functionality and subsequent coordination of enolic oxygen to the metal ion after proton replacement. A new band appearing at ca. 1281cm−1 is assigned to the ν(CO)(enolic) stretching of the coordinated hydrazone fragment. The sharp band appearing at 1624cm−1 due to azomethine group moves towards lower wave number by 21cm−1 (in 1), 28cm−1 (in 2) is consistent with the coordination of azomethine nitrogen to the molybdenum. The band at 3350cm−1 corresponding to the free OH group of ligand is also present in complexes 1 and 2 possibly suggesting the presence of coordinated methanol. The presence of multiple bands of medium intensity observed in the region 2800–2900cm−1 in all complexes suggests the existence of CH2 group. In addition, the neat complex 1 displays two sharp bands at 910 and 932cm−1 due to the ν sym(OMoO) and ν asym(OMoO) modes, respectively. These bands are indicative of the presence of a cis-[MoVIO2] structure. In the corresponding polymer-bound molybdenum complex these bands do not resolve clearly due to poor loading of metal complex and only one band was observed at 904cm−1. The chloromethylated polystyrene displays strong peaks at 1264 and 673cm−1 due to CHwag (CH2Cl) and CClstretch, respectively [41]. The absence of these peaks in PS-[MoVIO2((hap-iah)(MeOH)] (2) suggests the covalent bonding of chloromethylated polystyrene with [MoVIO2((hap-iah)(MeOH)] (cf. Scheme 2) through nitrogen of the indole ring. The absence of ν(NH)indole band appearing at 3052cm−1 in 1 further supplements this statement. 3.6 UV-visible spectral study The UV–vis spectra of the ligand (I) and neat complex (1) measured in methanol are shown in Fig. 3 (A) while Table S1 includes spectral data. Three ligand absorption bands are observed at 220, 274, and 319nm which are assigned to σ→σ*, π→π* and n → π* transitions, respectively. Similar kind of absorption bands with slight shift are also observed in complex 1. Complex 1 also exhibits a charge transfer band at 373nm originating due to transfer of partial electron density from phenolate oxygen atom to an empty d-orbital of the molybdenum atom. Spectrum of 2 recorded in Nujol® has very similar but weak electronic spectral patterns [Fig. 3(B)]. Bands in the UV region are similar to that observed in 1 but the expected LMCT transition in 2 could only be observed around 370nm as a weak shoulder in Nujol possibly due to poor loading of complex in the polymer matrix. 3.7 1H and 13C NMR studies The 1H NMR spectra of H2hap-iah (I) and [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (1) are shown in Fig. 4 and their typical chemical shifts are presented in Table S2. The 1H NMR spectrum of ligand exhibits three signals at δ = 13.21 (s, 1H), 11.14 (s, 1H), and 10.92 (s, 1H) ppm for phenolic OH, NH (of C(O)NH group) and NH (of indole) protons, respectively. The absence of signal due to NH of C(O)NH group in 1 supports the enolisation of the ketonic group and consequent replacement of H by the metal ion. Similarly, absence of phenolic proton signal in 1 indicates the coordination of the phenolic oxygen after proton replacement. Protons associated with aromatic, methyl (of o-hydroxyacetophenone), and NH (of indole group) groups appear at nearly same positions in ligand as well as in complex. In addition, methyl and OH protons of methanol were observed at δ =3.17 (s, 3H) and 4.1 (b, 1H) ppm, respectively. Table 2 provides 13C NMR spectral data of H2hap-iah (I) and [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH] (1) and Fig. S2 reproduces their spectra. For aromatic carbons less number of signals was observed due to the presence of center of symmetry. A large coordination-induced shift for C1 (carbon bearing phenolic oxygen), C7 (carbon bearing azomethine nitrogen), and C8 (carbon bearing enolic oxygen) atoms demonstrate the coordination of these functionalities to the molybdenum. A considerable up field shift of C9 (methylene) carbon, and down field shift of C18 (methyl) carbon was also noticed in complex. The signal of co-ordinated MeOH in 13C NMR could not be located possibly due to the replacement of MeOH by DMSO in solution. However, this could be located at δ =51.0ppm in CDCl3. 3.8 Catalytic activity studies 3.8.1 Oxidation of styrene with H2O2 in presence of NaHCO3 catalyzed by PS-[MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (2) At least five oxidation products have been obtained using polymer-anchored catalysts PS-[VIVO(sal-ohyba)·DMF] [6] and PS-K[VVO(O2)(L)] [L=2-(2-pyridyl) benzimidazole and 2-(3-pyridyl) benzimidazole] [42]. The oxidation of styrene, catalyzed by polymer supported complex PS-[MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (2), using aqueous 30% H2O2 as oxidant did not proceed. Addition of NaHCO3 to the reaction mixture activated the catalytic oxidation process efficiently and gave mainly styrene oxide along with small amount of un-identified product; Scheme 3 . Such NaHCO3 assisted oxidation of styrene has been reported in the literature [31–34,43]. The reaction conditions were optimized for the maximum oxidation of styrene, considering different parameters like amounts of catalyst, H2O2, NaHCO3, volume of CH3CN and effect of temperature. In order to optimize the catalyst amount, three different amounts of catalyst i.e., 0.010, 0.020, and 0.030g were taken for the fixed amount of styrene (0.52g, 5mmol), H2O2 (1.70g, 15mmol) and NaHCO3 (0.168g, 2mmol) in 5mL CH3CN solvent and the reaction was carried out at 60°C for 4h. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), a maximum of 31% conversion was achieved with 0.010g of catalyst in 4h of reaction time. This conversion improved to 59% upon increasing the catalyst amount to 0.020g. Further increasing the amount to 0.030g, the conversion of styrene improved to 68%. Therefore, 0.030g of catalyst was taken for the maximum conversion of styrene. The amount of NaHCO3 was optimized by taking 0.5, 1, and 2mmol of NaHCO3 under above reaction conditions; Fig. 5(b). A maximum of 30% conversion was obtained with 0.5mmol (0.042g) NaHCO3 in 4h of reaction time. Increasing this amount to 1mmol (0.084g) the conversion improved to 38% and 68% conversion of styrene was obtained with 2mmol (0.168g) of NaHCO3. To understand the effect of oxidant, three different styrene: aqueous 30% H2O2 molar ratios viz. 1:1, 1:2, and 1:3 were considered for a fixed amount of styrene (0.52g, 5mmol), NaHCO3 (0.168g, 2mmol) and catalyst (0.030g) in 5mL of CH3CN. As illustrated in Fig. 5(c), increasing the styrene to oxidant ratio from 1:1 to 1:2 increases the conversion from 25% to 52% and further increasing this ratio to 1:3 shows 68% conversion. Thus, substrate to H2O2 ratio of 1:3 was considered the best one for the maximum oxidation of styrene. The volume of acetonitrile was optimized by using three different volume of acetonitrile (5, 10, and 15mL); Fig. 5(d). In 5mL acetonitrile the conversion was 68% while increasing the volume of solvent did not improve any conversion. Under above optimized reaction conditions, temperature of the reaction mixture was also optimized and found that 60°C is the most suitable one to obtained highest conversion as shown in Fig. 5(e). Table 3 summarizes all conditions and conversion obtained under particular condition. From the data presented in Table 3, it is clear that the best suited reaction conditions for the maximum oxidation of 5mmol of styrene at 60°C are (entry no. 3): PS-[Mo VI O2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (0.030g), NaHCO3 (0.168g, 2mmol), aqueous 30% H2O2 (1.70g, 15mmol) and acetonitrile (5mL). The reaction was also carried out at room temperature under the same conditions in the presence of NaHCO3 only and it gave 16% conversion of styrene. A blank reaction (i.e., in the absence of catalyst while using H2O2 and NaHCO3) under the above reaction conditions gave 19% conversion while in the absence of NaHCO3 no reaction takes place. All these suggest the important role of NaHCO3 in assisting the catalytic ability of complex. Under the above optimised reaction conditions the neat complex [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (1) and recovered polymer anchored catalyst gave 66% and 65% conversion, respectively. Thus, catalytic potential of supported as well as neat complexes both are good but the recyclability of the supported catalyst makes it better over the non-supported one. 3.8.2 Oxidation of cyclohexene with H2O2 in presence of NaHCO3 catalyzed by PS-[MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (2) We have also tested the NaHCO3 assisted catalytic activity of 2 for the oxidation of cyclohexene using 30% H2O2 in acetonitrile and cyclohexene oxide was obtained as the major product (Scheme 4 ) along with some minor products but their overall percentage is extremely low. About 3h was required to acquire equilibrium with maximum conversion. The obtained main product was confirmed by GC–MS after its extraction by n-hexane from the reaction mixture. The reaction conditions for the maximum oxidation of cyclohexene were also optimized considering all these parameters stated above such as amounts of catalyst, aqueous 30% H2O2, NaHCO3, volume of acetonitrile, and temperature of the reaction mixture. Thus, for 5mmol (0.41g) of cyclohexene, four different amounts of catalyst (0.010, 0.020, 0.030, and 0.040g), 30% aqueous H2O2 (5, 7.5, 10, and 15mmol), NaHCO3 (1, 1.5, 2, and 3 mmol) were taken in acetonitrile (3, 5, 7, and 10mL) and the reaction was carried out at different temperatures (30, 40, 50, and 60°C). Fig. S3 presents whole profiles under different reactions conditions and Table 4 summarizes all the conditions and conversions obtained under a particular set of conditions. The best suited reaction conditions concluded (entry no. 16 of Table 4) with 93% conversion of cyclohexene are: catalyst (0.030g), 30% aqueous H2O2 (1.135g, 10mmol) and NaHCO3 (0.126g, 1.5mmol) in acetonitrile (3mL) at 50°C. A maximum of 40% conversion of cyclohexene was obtained without catalyst (i.e., in the presence of H2O2 and NaHCO3) under above reaction conditions while no conversion was obtained in the absence of NaHCO3. The oxidation of cyclohexene under same conditions at room temperature gave 32% conversion (Table 4). The catalyst remains insoluble in the above reaction conditions and, hence can be easily separated by simple filtration and reactivated by washing with CH3CN and drying. The oxidation of cyclohexene was also carried out with the recycled catalyst under the optimized reaction conditions. Only a small decrease in conversion (1%) shows that the catalyst is stable and reusable. A 91% conversion was obtained with [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (1). Thus, neat as well as supported catalysts both enhances the reaction while the recyclability of the supported catalyst makes it better over the non-supported one. 3.9 Reactivity of [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (1) with H2O2 and NaHCO3 and possible reaction pathway It is well known fact that cis-dioxidomolybdenum(VI) complexes give the corresponding [MoVIO(O2)]2+ complexes on treatment with H2O2 [6,30]. Starting from 1 such peroxidomolybdenum(VI) complex could not be isolated possibly due to its poor stability. However, its formation in methanol could be established by electronic absorption spectroscopy by reacting it with H2O2. Thus, drop wise addition of a dilute H2O2 solution (one drop 30% H2O2 dissolved in 10mL of MeOH) to 20mL of 3.33×10−4 M solution of 1 results in the spectroscopic changes presented in Fig. 6 . The band at 373nm shifts to 390nm with isosbestic point at 418nm along with decrease in intensity (inset ‘(a)’ of Fig. 6). Further, addition of up to 10 drops of above H2O2 solution results in only gain in intensity of this band (inset ‘(b)’ of Fig. 6). In diluted methanolic solution (5.32×10−5 M) of 1, the intensity of bands at 318 and 275nm increases and the intensity of band at 222nm remains nearly constant without much shifting (Fig. 6). These changes should indicate the interaction of [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (1) with H2O2 and the plausible formation of [MoVIO(O2)(hap-iah)(MeOH)] in methanol; Eq. (1). [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)]+H2O2 →[MoVIO(O2)(hap-iah)(MeOH)]+H2O (1) We have also carried out similar titration of [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (1) with H2O2 in the presence of NaHCO3 to understand their combined effect during catalytic action. Thus, after adding only few drops of a mixture of NaHCO3 and H2O2 exactly similar spectral changes, as observed by adding reasonable amount of H2O2 alone to 1, was obtained hinting the quick formation of oxidoperoxido species (Fig. S4). Literature reports the formation of HCO4 − (peroxymonocarbonate) instantly [31–34] on reaction of NaHCO3 with H2O2. This species reacts with [MoVIO2]2+ complex to generate [MoVIO(O2)]2+ intermediate more rapidly compared to H2O2 alone following another intermediate species as shown in Scheme 5 [33,34,43]. Thus, efficient formation of intermediate [MoVIO(O2)]2+ species enhances the transfer of oxygen to the substrate during catalytic oxidation to give final product. 4 Conclusions Complex [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (1) with H2hap-iah (I), a dibasic tridentate ONO donor ligand derived from o-hydroxyacetophenone and indole-3-acetic hydrazide, has been prepared. Complex 1 has also been grafted successfully in chloromethylated polystyrene cross-linked with 5% divinylbenzene (PS) through covalent bonding of the nitrogen of the indole group. NaHCO3 assisted oxidation of styrene and cyclohexene has been carried out by grafted complex {PS-[MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (2)} using aqueous H2O2 as oxidant. Styrene under optimized reaction conditions gave mainly styrene oxide as oxidized product while oxidation of cyclohexene gave cyclohexene oxide selectively. The intermediate peroxido species, expected to be involved during catalytic action, has also generated from solution of 1 and studied by UV–vis. The presence of some of the catalytic centers on the surface of the polymer, as detected by EDAX study possibly allowed their better interaction with substrates and oxidant during catalytic reaction resulting in better performance of the catalyst. The polymer-grafted complex shows better conversions than its neat counterpart. The polymer-grafted complex also provides additional advantage over its homogeneous counterpart in terms of recyclable catalytic system, increased catalyst lifetime, and easier separation from the reaction mixture. Acknowledgements M.R.M. and N.K. thank the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research, New Delhi, India [01(2447)/10-EMR-II] for financial support. coredata.dc:description: Ligand H2hap-iah (I), obtained by the condensation of equimolar amounts of o-hydroxy acetophenone (hap) and indole-3-acetic hydrazide (iah) reacts with [MoVIO2(acac)2] in 1:1 ratio in refluxing methanol to give [MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (1). Complex 1 has been grafted in chloromethylated polystyrene cross-linked with 5% divinylbenzene {now abbreviated as PS-[MoVIO2(hap-iah)(MeOH)] (2)} via covalent bonding through imino nitrogen of the indole group. Both complexes are characterized by various spectroscopic techniques (IR, electronic, 1H, and 13C NMR), analytical and thermal studies. Complex 2 has also been analyzed by atomic force microscopy (AFM), field-emission scanning electron micrographs (FE-SEM) as well as energy dispersive X-ray (EDAX) studies. The polymer-grafted compound 2 was used for the catalytic oxidation of styrene and cyclohexene in the presence of NaHCO3 using aqueous H2O2 as oxidant. The intermediate peroxido species, expected to be involved during catalytic action, was also generated from the solution of 1 and studied by UV–vis. Various reaction conditions were considered to optimize reactions conditions for the maximum oxidation of substrates. Styrene under optimized reaction conditions gave mainly styrene oxide as a major product. Oxidation of cyclohexene gave cyclohexene oxide selectively. The polymer-grafted complex shows higher conversions than its neat counterpart. The polymer-grafted complex provides additional advantage over its homogeneous counterpart in terms of increased catalyst lifetime and easier separation from the reaction mixture and allows for recyclable catalytic system.
coredata.dc:title: Sodium bicarbonate assisted oxidation, by H2O2, of styrene and cyclohexene using polymer grafted dioxidomolybdenum(VI) complex as a catalyst
